headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michelle. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Limited Brands First Quarter Earnings Conference Call for the period ending Saturday, April 30, 2011. As a matter of formality, I need to remind you that any forward-looking statements we may make
componenttext:
Thanks, Michelle. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Limited Brands First Quarter Earnings Conference Call for the period ending Saturday, April 30, 2011. 
As a matter of formality, I need to remind you that any forward-looking statements we may make today are subject to our Safe Harbor statement found in our SEC filings. Our first quarter earnings per share release and related financial information, including any non-GAAP or adjusted financial reconciliation tables are available on our website, limitedbrands.com. Also available on our website is an investor presentation, which we will be referring to during this call. This call is being taped and can be replayed by dialing 1-866-NEWS-LTD. You can also listen to an audio replay from our website. 
Stuart Burgdorfer, EVP and CFO; Sharen Turney, CEO of Victoria's Secret; Diane Neal, CEO of Bath & Body Works; and Martyn Redgrave, EVP and Chief Administrative Officer are all joining us today. After our prepared comments, we will be available to take your questions for as long as time permits. So that we can speak to as many callers as possible, please limit yourself to one question. Thanks, and now I'll turn the call over to Stuart.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Amie, and good morning, everyone. We're pleased with our record first quarter performance. Our adjusted earnings per share increased 60% to $0.40 per share versus $0.25 last year. Our reported results was $0.50 per share versus $0.34 last year. Bo
componenttext:
Thanks, Amie, and good morning, everyone. We're pleased with our record first quarter performance. Our adjusted earnings per share increased 60% to $0.40 per share versus $0.25 last year. Our reported results was $0.50 per share versus $0.34 last year. Both this and last year's reported results include significant items as detailed in our press release. This year's reported first quarter results include the following: A pretax gain from the sale from Express shares of $86.4 million or $0.17 per share. A pretax non-cash expense of $50 million or $0.10 per share related to the multiyear funding of our charitable foundation. We plan to fund this commitment by contributing about 1/3 of our remaining investment in Express shares, which allows us to meet our commitment in a tax efficient manner. After this contribution, we will continue to own approximately 5 million shares of Express stock. Also excluded is an income tax benefit of $11 million or $0.03 per share related to the favorable resolution of certain income tax matters. 
The 2010 reported result includes a pretax gain of $48.7 million or $0.09 per share related to a cash distribution from Express. All results discussed on this call exclude these significant items in both years. Our first quarter earnings per share of $0.40 per share significantly exceeded our beginning of the quarter expectations of between $0.26 and $0.31 per share. This upside was driven by the 15% comp increase versus our initial forecast of about 2% to 4%. 
To take you through the first quarter results as detailed on Page 4 of the presentation, net sales were $2.217 billion versus $1.932 billion last year and comps increased 15%. The gross margin rate increased 200 basis points to 38%, primarily driven by leverage on buying and occupancy expense. The merchandise margin rate increased slightly despite a negative impact of about 80 basis points related to the increase in MAST sales to Express and Limited Stores, which are recognized at 100% this year versus 75% last year. This accounting change, which occurs-ed in the third quarter of 2010 will continue to have a negative impact on our consolidated merchandise margin rate in the second quarter. 
SG&A dollars increased by $65.6 million or 13% and the SG&A rate improved by 40 basis points. Total expenses, including buying and occupancy, increased by 10%. Three quarters of our SG&A expense growth relate to investments that we made in store selling and marketing to support and drive sales growth. 
Store selling cost increased by 12% and leverage as a percent of sales. Marketing cost increased by about 20% and deleverage slightly as we invested in the quarter in initiatives to drive sales, including media and in-store visual merchandising and marketing. The remaining increase in SG&A relates to growth in our home office expense across various categories, including investments related to our International business, merit increases and incentive compensation. 
Turning to our operating income on Page 5. Total operating income increased by $81.8 million or 44% and 250 basis points as a percent of sales to $266.8 million or 12% of sales. By segment, the Victoria's Secret segment increased by $72.4 million or 340 basis points as a percent of sales to $239.7 million or 16.6% of sales. Bath & Body Works increased by $16.5 million or 250 basis points as a percent of sales to $54.2 million or 11.3% of sales. And the other segment operating loss increased by $7 million to $21.7 million driven primarily by an increase in a certain $27.1 million driven primarily by an increase in certain legal reserves. Total nonoperating expenses increased by $7.8 million as the loss of income from Express and Limited Stores was partially offset by a decline in interest expense. 
Turning to the balance sheet on Page 6. Retail inventories per square foot at cost ended the quarter down 5% versus last year and down 20% on a 2-year basis. Excluding an increase in the first quarter of 2009 related to the full quarter of inventories associated with Victoria's Secret systems implementation, inventory per square foot has decreased for 16 consecutive quarters. As you know, we issued 1 billion of tender notes during the first quarter at an interest rate of 6 5/8%. We repurchased 16.7 million shares of stock in the first quarter for $590 million, and we also just announced a new 500 million share repurchase program. 
Turning to Page 7 of our presentation for our forecast for 2011. We expect earnings per share between $0.38 and $0.43 in the second quarter. This forecast reflects a low- to mid-single-digit comp increase. We expect the second quarter gross margin rate to increase and the SG&A rate to be roughly flat to last year. We expect to end the second quarter with inventory per square foot roughly flat to up slightly to last year. 
For the full year, we are projecting low- to mid-single-digit positive comps. We continue to expect some impact from increasing cost pressures this fall, and therefore, our outlook does call for some decline in our merchandise margin rate in 2011. We believe that this decline will be more than offset by buying and occupancy leverage, so our forecast for our 2011 gross margin rate to be up slightly to last year. 
We expect the full year SG&A expense rate to leverage slightly on total sales growth. Nonoperating expenses are projected at about $65 million per quarter consisting principally of interest -- of interest expense. This forecast is about $17 million higher than our previous guidance driven by the new notes. Before any discrete items, our tax rate will be approximately 38%. We are forecasting weighted average shares of about 318 million in the second quarter and the full year, which resumes that we will complete the share repurchase program near the end of the year. Assuming all of these inputs, we expect earnings per share for the full year of 2011 to be between $2.25 and $2.45 per share. We are now projecting 2011 CapEx of about $400 million to $425 million. As detailed on Page 8 of the presentation, we plan to open roughly 40 stores this year and close roughly 50 stores. We'll enter the year with total square footage roughly flat to last year. 
Turning to liquidity. We expect free cash flow in 2011 of about $650 million, and we remain committed to returning excess cash to shareholders through a combination of share repurchases and dividends. Our free cash flow and cash position, along with the additional availability under our revolving credit facility resulted in very strong liquidity, which is more than sufficient to fund our working capital, capital expenditures, dividends and any other foreseeable needs. Thanks, and now I'll turn the discussion over to Sharen.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: thank you, Stuart, and good morning, everyone. Victoria's Secret funds record operating profit in the first quarter. We are pleased with this result, and I will begin my comments this morning by discussing what we believe have been the key driver of our s
componenttext:
thank you, Stuart, and good morning, everyone. Victoria's Secret funds record operating profit in the first quarter. We are pleased with this result, and I will begin my comments this morning by discussing what we believe have been the key driver of our success. I'll follow this with review of first quarter financial results and will then briefly discuss how we are thinking about the second quarter. 
So let's begin with what we have been doing to deliver our results. We continue to stay very focused on our core categories, bras and panties, coupled with a culture that emphasizes giving faster and more agile every day. We remained purposeful in our balanced approach between managing the business with optimism and staying conservative on our inventory and expense plans, and we are carefully bringing all of our work together and a well-told brand story across channel. We are telling that story through innovative products, steady newness, the right fashion and excellent in-store and online execution. 
Our customer connection has been critical to our success. We work everyday to stay close to her and deliver an emotional and positive experience with every interaction. An example of our connectivity and our brand strength is our Facebook presence. We are the top specialty retailer. In fact, in March, our Victoria's Secret and Pink pages were the 2 most liked pages of all retailers, something we're very proud. 
Finally, at the very core of our success, are the people who make it happen each and everyday. We have a seasoned and dedicated leadership team across all of our key function. Our leaders have been in place and working together now for a number of years, and I feel very good about our talent from design to merchandising stores, operations, marketing and, really, across the business, both in the home office and in the field. 
Now turning to our financial performance. Our first quarter results are detailed on Page 9 of your presentation material. In the Victoria's Secret stores channel, first quarter comp and total sales were up 19% versus last year, with total sales increasing to $986.6 million. This result was driven by strength across the assortment with fewer in-store promotion and on inventory levels that were significantly below our sales growth. Our Lingerie business demonstrate balanced growth in bras and panties and sleepwear all performing well. We had a success Valentine's Day weekend and offered customers newness throughout the quarter. This included new styles and fashion in many areas of the business, including the Incredible, Gorgeous and Dream Angels bra collection, as well as our innovative Incredible panties and Miraculous swimwear. Pink delivered another very strong performance with growth across the assortment both by base business and strong customers' response to Pink's ongoing newness. We introduced a number of new Pink bras in Q1, and we are pleased with the progress and opportunities we see in this category. 
Our Beauty business also performed well in the first quarter. Customers loved our fragrance and other new product introductions, and we continue to improve the Beauty business integration and coordination with the balance of the store. We began this last fall with the co-launch of Beauty and Lingerie products to the Bombshell bra and fragrance launches and continued this in the first quarter with Incredible and a Dream Angels launches. 
As with prior quarters, in-store execution has been a key contributor to our sales growth, and we again achieved record customer conversion for the quarter. First quarter merchandise margin dollars were up significantly on roughly flat margin rate. Additionally, first quarter growth and operating margins both improved significantly, and combined with our top line, drove our operating profit nearly 50% versus last year. 
Now, let's review Direct performance. First quarter sales increased 5% to $369 million. The top line was driven by strength in bras, Pink, swim and dresses, but that strength was partially offset by stoutness in other parts of the Apparel business. Sales growth was also negatively affected by a very intentional strategy to reduce the number of days we were on promotion and to carry far less clearance inventory into the season. 
The gross margin rate increased significantly driven by the strategy to reduce promotional and clearance selling, as well as the strength in the assortment, enabling us to drive significantly more business at regular price. Additionally, total expense leverage to operating income dollars increased nearly 25%, and the operating income rate was up significantly to last year. 
Looking ahead to the second quarter, we will continue to do more of what works. We will focus on providing customers fresh, innovative products with high-emotional content. We will stay balanced in our approach, executing with discipline, simplicity and speed. And we will be thoughtful in our inventory and expense plan, investing in customer impacting initiative to drive sustained results. In closing, we are pleased with our performance and see opportunities for improvement. Above all else, we will stay close to our customer and work to drive, sustained, profitable growth as our top priority. Thanks, and now I'll turn the discussion over to Diane.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sharen, and good morning. As I'm sure most of you have already heard by now, since we made the announcement on Tuesday, that I decide to return to San Francisco, which would require me to leave my role as CEO of Bath & Body Works. As you can al
componenttext:
Thank you, Sharen, and good morning. As I'm sure most of you have already heard by now, since we made the announcement on Tuesday, that I decide to return to San Francisco, which would require me to leave my role as CEO of Bath & Body Works. As you can all imagine, this has been a very difficult decision, as I have an amazing team, we have great momentum in the business, and we've accomplished so much over the last 4 years. However, my personal life has been on the West Coast and offer to create more balance, I decided to relocate. The good news is that I will be transitioning to advisory role to help on-board Nick Ko [ph] who was formerly President at Land's End, who will be joining us in early July. 
For those of you who haven't met Nick yet, let me assure that the brand will be in very capable hands. Nick has an incredible track record of merchant and he is as customer-centric as we are at Bath & Body Works. I am convinced that the brand will continue to deliver incredible results under his leadership. 
So let me discuss Bath & Body Works results for the first quarter. We were able to deliver significant sales and operating income growth versus last year. We continue to deliver improved results versus strong performance last year by maintaining focus on our 3 key categories, which are Signature Collection product line, the Soap and Sanitizer business and our home fragrance assortment. 
Performance improved on top of strong results last year and Signature Collection driven by the launches of new fragrances that Carried Away and Country Chic, as well as the relaunch of our already very successful fragrance, Japanese Cherry Blossom. The Anti business, driven by our Hand Soap and Sanitizer business. Performance in those businesses was driven by increasing fragrance and fashion newness and bath and soap collection. 
Our Home Fragrance sales also grew versus strong performance last year and continue to be driven by candles and new seasonal fragrances, as well as growth in new forms and novelties in our diffuser category. Transactions were up versus last year driven by traffic and improvement in our conversion rate. Customers also spent more per transaction versus last year. So with that backdrop, let me take you to the financial results for the quarter. [indiscernible]  At the presentation, Bath & Body Works first quarter comps were up 11%. Total sales for the quarter were $480 million, up 11% or $49 million versus last year. First quarter, our operating income was $54 million, which was up $16 million or 44% from last year. Operating income as a percentage of sales is 11% in the quarter and up significantly to last year. Operating income was driven by the positive comps, modest improvement in merchandise margin rate and expense leverage, both buying occupancy and SG&A leveraged in the first quarter. 
We also finished the quarter with inventory levels down to last year, and we continue to drive inventory down year-over-year while the in-stock positions continue to improve. The Bath & Body Works Direct channel also delivered strong sales and operating income growth versus last year. In the second quarter, we will continue to introduce newness and innovation in both form and fragrance. This month, we launched our newest Signature Collection fragrance Into The Wild, and we'll also launch a new collection of coconut-inspired fragrances. The Anti-Bac and Home Fragrance businesses will also introduce of fashion and newness in fragrances and in form. 
We're cautiously optimistic about the second quarter, and we will continue to manage expenses and inventories conservatively. Our focus will continue to be faster and better in understanding and satisfying our customers' needs while providing them with a world-class, in-store experience. In addition to focusing on product and fragrance launches, we will continue to test and read the results of new product offerings and promotional strategies while maintaining flexibility and our inventories to react quickly to our customers needs. 
Earlier I mentioned that the brand will be in good hands with Nick, but I should also say that the brand will be in that fantastic hands now with Nick and entire senior leadership team that Andrew Maslow [indiscernible] and the entire BBW team. So with that, I'm going to turn the discussion over to Martin.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Diane, and good morning, everyone. On our last earnings call, I spent quite a bit of time to updating you on our strategy to grow international businesses. The summary of what we covered on the call is that we recognize that we have tremendous int
componenttext:
Thanks, Diane, and good morning, everyone. On our last earnings call, I spent quite a bit of time to updating you on our strategy to grow international businesses. The summary of what we covered on the call is that we recognize that we have tremendous international growth opportunities for all of our brands as we expand outside the United States. We remain on track in the execution of our international strategy and continue to be very pleased with the performance of all of our new international stores. 
As you can see on Page 11 of the presentation, we, along with our partners, will open approximately 100 to 135 new stores this year. In the first quarter, our partners opened 7 new international La Senza locations is and one Travel and Tourism store, which by the way, we're now calling the Victoria's Secret Beauty and Accessories stores, a change in name that clarifies, I think, the brand positioning of that concept. 
By just after the close of the quarter, we opened 2 more Victoria's Secret stores in Canada and the customer response to all of these new stores has been terrific. And before we take your questions, I'll close my comments by discussing La Senza's first quarter performance. Total sales increased 3% to $88.3 million in the first quarter. This was driven by foreign currency translation and a mid-single-digit increase in reported revenue in the International businesses, which was partially offset by a 4% comp in the Canadian stores. Our broad categories delivered modest growth, led by the launch of our Body and the continued success of our Hello Sugar and [indiscernible] styles. The gross margin rate declined driven by a significant decline in merchandise margin rate. 
Increase in the merchandise margin rate was driven by a mix shift to the International business, which has a lower margin rate, and also by a decline in Canadian stores, and that was driven higher foreign currency and increased promotional activity. The operating loss improved slightly on a dollar basis and significantly on a rate basis. 
We're encouraged in the Bra business and continue to be focused on refining our assortment and establishing a strong brand that resonates with our target customers. However, it is clear our La Senza business remains a work in progress. 
So in closing, I want to reiterate that we continue to be pleased with the company's overall performance, which was driven by an intense focus on the fundamentals, coupled with an orientation of getting faster and more agile and also staying close to our customers. We'll maintain this discipline and focused approach, and we clearly see opportunities to continue to get even better. Thanks, and I'll now turn it back over to Amie for questions.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Very nice quarter here. I wanted to ask if heard about the SG&A leverage point? I know that historically you've said typically when you beat your same-store sales growth plans, you're somewhere between 30% and 50% of those incremental dollars flow-through
componenttext: Very nice quarter here. I wanted to ask if heard about the SG&A leverage point? I know that historically you've said typically when you beat your same-store sales growth plans, you're somewhere between 30% and 50% of those incremental dollars flow-through the operating income line. I think this is the second quarter in a row where the flow-through rate has been slightly lower than that. So I'm just wondering if you can step back from the noise of the last couple of quarters and talk about how you think the flow-through rate should come in future quarters?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question. I mean, it's a balancing act as you all appreciate. I don't know how many of you have heard the expression, you don't take great comps to the bank, you take dollars home to do the bank. So there's a lot of things that we think abo
componenttext: Thanks for the question. I mean, it's a balancing act as you all appreciate. I don't know how many of you have heard the expression, you don't take great comps to the bank, you take dollars home to do the bank. So there's a lot of things that we think about. The first is just to reiterate quickly, operating profit dollars in the quarter were up 40%. The margin rate, operating margin rate improved by 250 basis points to 12%. And clearly, as we look at expenses, while the geography in our P&L kind of highlights SG&A, there's a lot of home office and other important expenses within gross margin in the buying and occupancy line, and those expenses in aggregate grew about 10%, which was about 500 basis points lower than sales. So we are making investments to drive growth, sales growth and longer-term growth. We think on an overall basis, those investments are paying off. But to your point, the leverage might not be as great as one might cancel out on paper, but the investments we're making are absolutely contributing meaningfully to the topline growth and the dollar profitability of the business. With all that's said, we continue to look at everything very closely and within the brands, within the overall corporation, we continue to look and how we do it. But we think, overall, we're advancing pretty well.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro of The Retail Tracker.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro of The Retail Tracker.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Diane, you'll be very missed. So my question is out to you. You've done a great job in BBW, in particular things like pocket bac. So could you talk about the philosophy behind here, and do you plan to expand the store? And, I guess, is Nick on-board and f
componenttext: Diane, you'll be very missed. So my question is out to you. You've done a great job in BBW, in particular things like pocket bac. So could you talk about the philosophy behind here, and do you plan to expand the store? And, I guess, is Nick on-board and fully vested in what you're trying to do here?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Marni, first of all, thank you for saying that. And Nick is not fully on-board until July, he'll be on-boarding with me at that point. But as far as fashion, we continue to work not only the pocket bac category. We've done across all of our categories by
componenttext: Marni, first of all, thank you for saying that. And Nick is not fully on-board until July, he'll be on-boarding with me at that point. But as far as fashion, we continue to work not only the pocket bac category. We've done across all of our categories by the amount of newness we have across soaps and Signature and Home Fragrance, almost double, and we'll continue with that cadence. And we continue to look at our business at how much basic fragrances do we need on a year-round basis. And we continue to read out when we don't need them, and continue to pump up in the seasonal things than we're coming in as well as fashion. So, I mean, it's our business now is a fashion business across all the categories, which is actually pretty exciting, and that helps us add to the top line than having a basic commodity business. So I anticipate that continuing. And Nick's got a lot of fashion in his background, so I think he'll continue what we started.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Janet Kloppenburg from JJK Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Janet Kloppenburg from JJK Research.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on a wonderful quarter. Stuart, I was hoping you could talk a little bit more about the SG&A spending. I think it has to do with increase in the payroll on the stores to boost customer service, and I'm wondering if the rate of spend will c
componenttext: Congratulations on a wonderful quarter. Stuart, I was hoping you could talk a little bit more about the SG&A spending. I think it has to do with increase in the payroll on the stores to boost customer service, and I'm wondering if the rate of spend will continue to come at similar levels throughout the year or if there'll be a modification in the back half? And if you could help us understand the success level of that project. And also for, Diane, I wanted to say thank you very much for your wonderful leadership, and I was just wondering how long your advisory role you would hold that for the company?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and we'll go to Stuart first.
componenttext: Thank you, and we'll go to Stuart first.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: So, Janet, on the first thing on kind of SG&A expenses and what we're doing and how we're thinking about it and how it may play through for the whole year. The first thing that we're committed to and it's a shared view across the business is that we're go
componenttext: So, Janet, on the first thing on kind of SG&A expenses and what we're doing and how we're thinking about it and how it may play through for the whole year. The first thing that we're committed to and it's a shared view across the business is that we're going to grow expenses lower than sales. So I want to reiterate that and ensure that's clear for everybody that's following us. We will grow expenses lower than sales. And then what I would, in some form repeat, it's the key message is. With that said, we're going to invest in a lot of things whether it's working to serve customers better through a better experience in our stores or better visual display in our stores, more effective visual display or more compelling marketing. We're going to invest in those types of things, all of which are in SG&A in what we believe that we're getting paid for that work that customers notice and then it drives growth in sales, and that's what we're doing. We'll continue to do that as any reasonable business would. And what can you expect for the balance of the year is all that, but again with the commitment and expenses were lower than sales. We're not going to go a lot more detail about the specific aspects of those investments for reasons I hope you can understand in terms of we think some of those things can create some competitive advantage...

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's really paying off, Stuart, I just wanted to know if...
componenttext: I think it's really paying off, Stuart, I just wanted to know if...

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: We think it is too. We appreciate your acknowledgment of that, and we're happy with the growth in the business, the experience that customers are having and the profit growth of the business. So thanks for the comment.
componenttext: We think it is too. We appreciate your acknowledgment of that, and we're happy with the growth in the business, the experience that customers are having and the profit growth of the business. So thanks for the comment.

componenttext: Okay. And has the marketing and merchandising program for the holiday season been developed or will it be before you exit the company?

componenttextpreview: We basically have our merchandising and including the marketing piece together as we speak for holidays. So it'll pretty much it will be in place. But, as you know, managing the business day to day is pretty significant in our business.
componenttext: We basically have our merchandising and including the marketing piece together as we speak for holidays. So it'll pretty much it will be in place. But, as you know, managing the business day to day is pretty significant in our business.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dana Telsey from Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dana Telsey from Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: With Bath & Body Works and with Victoria's Secret, can you give us a little update on any cost pressures that you're seeing. I know obviously, it's much less than a lot of the other retailers. Any update there? And then just also inventory levels, which a
componenttext: With Bath & Body Works and with Victoria's Secret, can you give us a little update on any cost pressures that you're seeing. I know obviously, it's much less than a lot of the other retailers. Any update there? And then just also inventory levels, which appeared very lean. How do you think about the inventories for the balance of the year?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Dana, on costs, our views haven't changed much from what we communicated in February when we did our call and that is to reiterate some of that, 40% of our product is personal care and beauty. The biggest opportunity that we see at the end of the year is
componenttext: Dana, on costs, our views haven't changed much from what we communicated in February when we did our call and that is to reiterate some of that, 40% of our product is personal care and beauty. The biggest opportunity that we see at the end of the year is fashion to manage inventories tightly and with discipline with an appropriate balance of optimism and conservatism to continue to work down -- to reduce markdowns where we can, which are much more substantial opportunity frankly than the pressure of cost. But with that said, as we've communicated before and it's still our view and have reiterate at it again in our prepared comments, there is some cost pressure in the business. It'll be more weighted to the back half of the year, and we're going to work hard to offset as much of it as we can. But not -- in summary, to answer your question, not a lot of changes is viewed as we saw it a few months ago. With respect to inventories, similar in mindset to expenses, which is, as you know, it is a critical area for us. All of us, all the leaders of the business are pay very close attention to it, balancing, creating an appropriate range for customers, along with managing the risk of inventory and working hard to get better at greeting and reacting and chasing. We made good progress on that, but there's more that we can and will do. As I commented on, we think inventory in terms of the second quarter will be flat to up slightly, so it remains a continued area of focus for us and we remain to be very vigilant.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jennifer Davis, Lazard Capital Markets
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jennifer Davis, Lazard Capital Markets

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: A comment, a clarification and a question, if I may. First, Diane, congratulations to you. You've done an amazing job over the past couple of years. You really turned BBW into a fashion brand, so best of luck to you. And by the way, the in-store marketing
componenttext: A comment, a clarification and a question, if I may. First, Diane, congratulations to you. You've done an amazing job over the past couple of years. You really turned BBW into a fashion brand, so best of luck to you. And by the way, the in-store marketing at BBW looks amazing right now. Clarification, you guys have guided May comps up low-single-digits and haven't provided any updates. So since you didn't provide an update, should we assume that's there comps are trending now. And the, Stuart, any update on your 15% operating margin goal? I think that was based on 16% to 17% segment margin that Bath & Body Works and VS, and I'm actually modeling that this year. So comments there? Thanks.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, Janet, I'll take your first comment on May comps. We didn't update guidance, obviously, about May on in this call, but you shouldn't read that anything into that one way or another. And then, Stuart, for the 15% margin.
componenttext: Okay, Janet, I'll take your first comment on May comps. We didn't update guidance, obviously, about May on in this call, but you shouldn't read that anything into that one way or another. And then, Stuart, for the 15% margin.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, with respect to the 15% operating margin, our first focus to achieve that goal that we've set out more than 2 years ago, and we're working very hard collectively to do that. We've made good progress, as you know, separately as we start to approach t
componenttext: Well, with respect to the 15% operating margin, our first focus to achieve that goal that we've set out more than 2 years ago, and we're working very hard collectively to do that. We've made good progress, as you know, separately as we start to approach that goal or gets closer in our site. We do think about the full or true potential of our business, and we're starting to get more formal in our thinking, starting to get more formal in our thinking, including looking at other international and well-known retailers like [indiscernible] and others about what the full potential of Limited Brands is. And we think that certainly, can exceed 15%, but our focus is first to get to the 15%. As you point out, depending upon what one assumes, we can get to that goal on different time frames. We're working hard to get there as best as we can but doing so in a way that also ensures the long-term growth and health of the business. So we're making good progress. There's more we can do beyond it, but it's going to be like one step at a time.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011

componenttext: Question is really on the international side. Just curious maybe you guys could talk a little about how much less now is spending is timed on growing international? And then between the franchise, wholesale or your company-owned stores in London that you'll be opening, how do you think about sort of those paces of growth over the next few years? And outside of London, how you're going about maybe the next few cities that you guys will be looking at?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Brian, we're going to go to Martyn.
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Brian, we're going to go to Martyn.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the key thing to say about our commitment is he's very commitment and also our expansion outside of the United States. I mean people talk about the amount of time he spends on it, relatively speaking. But the fact is, he's committed to all the par
componenttext: I think the key thing to say about our commitment is he's very commitment and also our expansion outside of the United States. I mean people talk about the amount of time he spends on it, relatively speaking. But the fact is, he's committed to all the parts of the business and working very heart alongside of the rest of the management team to make all of that work. In terms of our international expansion plans, the things that we kind of discuss this in great detail or more detail on the year end earnings call, we remain on track with all the expansion plans that we've previously described. The London flagship store for next year as you called out is the next that beyond North America for Victoria's Secret. The expansion of Bath & Body Works outside the United States through our partners in the Middle East and Turkey is part of our plans for this year. And beyond that, geographically, in addition to that, the expansion of this Victoria's Secret Beauty and Accessories concept formerly no as T&T remains a priority for our global expansion. And in addition to that, the La Senza international business, which we're very committed to, working very hard on because we believe that brand is well-positioned for expansion globally. All of those remain on track and on plan. Geographically beyond that, we're continuing to be curious about other parts of the world, Asia, South America and elsewhere, and we've not yet decided on where we would go next.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jennifer Black with Jennifer Black and Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jennifer Black with Jennifer Black and Associates.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I have a question for you, over the last year, you ran a number of test for a BBW loyalty program. Most recently, you add BBW Club with a mobile app, and I wonder what your findings are? Do you believe these test programs have been effective? And does
componenttext: So I have a question for you, over the last year, you ran a number of test for a BBW loyalty program. Most recently, you add BBW Club with a mobile app, and I wonder what your findings are? Do you believe these test programs have been effective? And does a credit card make sense for your customer?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we're continuing -- first of all, thank you, Jennifer. We're continuing to read some of the other test that we have out there. We have mixed results depending on the type of test that we have and it challenge us on a whole other level to make this a
componenttext: Well, we're continuing -- first of all, thank you, Jennifer. We're continuing to read some of the other test that we have out there. We have mixed results depending on the type of test that we have and it challenge us on a whole other level to make this a little different, and I don't want to share too much of it, but it's to take a whole new level of how we look at the stores and kind of how the loyalty-type club programs are. So you'll probably be seeing a lot more test going forward into the fall season and into next year. But as far as the credit card, AURs are so low, and I don't know that if it still makes sense for us to have a credit card in our business.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's what I thought. Thanks so much.
componenttext: That's what I thought. Thanks so much.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Neely Tamminga with Piper Jaffray

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: My question is for Martyn or Stuart in terms of La Senza. I think going back in the days when you guys bought the business and kind of what the EBIT margin structure was there, and obviously so many things have changed since then. Just wanting to know wha
componenttext: My question is for Martyn or Stuart in terms of La Senza. I think going back in the days when you guys bought the business and kind of what the EBIT margin structure was there, and obviously so many things have changed since then. Just wanting to know what the roadmap is in terms of EBIT, contribution, how much it might be weighing on the overall entity? That'll be helpful. And just, again, gratitude and best wishes to Diane.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Martyn to that Neely.
componenttext: We'll go to Martyn to that Neely.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: La Senza as I mentioned via my brief remarks is, continues to be in process of transformation. I just want to remind everybody there are only 9 months into this process of transformation of La Senza. We relocated the management team. We got new leadership
componenttext: La Senza as I mentioned via my brief remarks is, continues to be in process of transformation. I just want to remind everybody there are only 9 months into this process of transformation of La Senza. We relocated the management team. We got new leadership team in place. We've now repositioned the brand in terms of its brand positioning to be more of a fun, flirty and sexy brand positioning. We repositioned the assortment to focus on bras and panties. All of that is a work in progress and only 9 months old. So knowing the track record we have for building brands, I would suggest we would need to be patient and stay the course. The other thing I'd say about Canada is if you tracked any of the competitive results in Canada, the Canadian retail market is actually quite challenging right now. While traffic is significant negative, and so in addition to the transformational challenges that the management team is working their way through the Canadian retail market, it has presented more headwinds that we're seeing in the United States.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Neely, this Stuart, just a quick follow-up. La Senza at this point is not contributing meaningfully to the profit of the company, so it's diluted our margin rate where it should be what should be in our view for any of our store-based businesses with bran
componenttext: Neely, this Stuart, just a quick follow-up. La Senza at this point is not contributing meaningfully to the profit of the company, so it's diluted our margin rate where it should be what should be in our view for any of our store-based businesses with brand equity and so on. It should be a 15% -- plus operating margin business. So with de background that Martyn provided financially, there's a big opportunity to improve this business.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Stacy Pak with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stacy Pak with Barclays Capital.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess I have 2 sort of fundamental questions. One is just on Victoria's Secret, you have this incredibly powerful brand, and it feels like you're tiptoeing internationally with it. You're leading with franchising, you're doing the Travel and Tourism. Wh
componenttext: I guess I have 2 sort of fundamental questions. One is just on Victoria's Secret, you have this incredibly powerful brand, and it feels like you're tiptoeing internationally with it. You're leading with franchising, you're doing the Travel and Tourism. Why are you not opening Victoria's Secret stores internationally more aggressively and when are you going to? And, I guess, the other question is what are you doing about Lulu and about Selma? And if you don't want to answer those 2, then just answer the category question. Are you going to leave those businesses alone? I know you're doing some stuff at East End on the VSX, maybe you can address that, as well as sort of the older mindset in Lingerie?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're actually going to go to Sharen first for the second part of your question, and then we'll go for Martyn for international.
componenttext: We're actually going to go to Sharen first for the second part of your question, and then we'll go for Martyn for international.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: We believe that the opportunity within the sport yoga world is a real one. And, as you know, we've been testing and playing with that concept for a while. And now we have the business really on a growth pattern. I think that you'll be seeing us getting mu
componenttext: We believe that the opportunity within the sport yoga world is a real one. And, as you know, we've been testing and playing with that concept for a while. And now we have the business really on a growth pattern. I think that you'll be seeing us getting much more aggressive about that concept as we go forward. In terms of the Selma question, we have a targeted customer in terms of the size band that we want to serve. And we, at this point, deviate from that as we go forward.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sharen, and Martyn?
componenttext: Thanks, Sharen, and Martyn?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's a challenging question because I know people can be frustrated about the pace. The best way for me to answer that is with the things that we've said very consistent in the past few years. #1, we're focused on our core brands in the United States. We
componenttext: It's a challenging question because I know people can be frustrated about the pace. The best way for me to answer that is with the things that we've said very consistent in the past few years. #1, we're focused on our core brands in the United States. We have great core brands in the United States with a great growth opportunities. Our international expansion there is paced at a rate that will not distract us from that first report primary mission. With the VS brand, we believe is a very complicated brand to deliver to the rest of the world because of the complex nature of the brand, the multi-sub-brand categories, the big box positioning, et cetera. The La Senza brand, the BBW brands are easier and less complicated, and that's the reason we've been focused on those brands principally in the early days. We're very encouraged by the results that we're seeing in Canada, not just the customer sales and profitability results but also the operating results. Now we've demonstrated that and we are able to operate big box with Victoria's Secret store outside the United States. Our next step in that dance will be the London store, and that will help us to demonstrate our ability operationally to do that across the ocean and do that well. And then beyond that, I think that will open the doors to further expansion of Victoria's Secret brand. But as Leslie said many times, we're going to be careful and cautious about the pace and make sure that we don't distract ourselves from the core mission of our U.S. business.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Lejuez with Nomura Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Lejuez with Nomura Securities.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: What month are you guys targeting for the London flagship opening? And, I guess, also what are your plans in the rest of the U.K.? Will you wait for that store to open, or are you already looking at other sites? And then, Stuart, just wondering what's beh
componenttext: What month are you guys targeting for the London flagship opening? And, I guess, also what are your plans in the rest of the U.K.? Will you wait for that store to open, or are you already looking at other sites? And then, Stuart, just wondering what's behind the higher CapEx numbers?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, the New Bond Street store that we're planning to opened in mid-2012 is a very complex store from construction and other points of view. And so are targeting that open in 2012, but we haven't kind of zeroed in on the exact opening date yet. Beyo
componenttext: Yes, Paul, the New Bond Street store that we're planning to opened in mid-2012 is a very complex store from construction and other points of view. And so are targeting that open in 2012, but we haven't kind of zeroed in on the exact opening date yet. Beyond that, yes, we are looking with additional real estate opportunities in the U.K. And with the assumption that this first store will be wildly successful, I would expect that we will expand the first store.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Paul, on the CapEx, 3 things. One is the number of new store openings has come up a little bit from the beginning of the year just opportunistic. And secondly, we are on a spectrum, during a few more things with respect to technology, nothing major. But a
componenttext: Paul, on the CapEx, 3 things. One is the number of new store openings has come up a little bit from the beginning of the year just opportunistic. And secondly, we are on a spectrum, during a few more things with respect to technology, nothing major. But a few more things with respect to technology than we thought about it at the beginning of the year. But again, it's still $420 million to $425 million, just up modestly.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Tubin with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Sharen. I think when you think about Victoria's Secret and as we're continuing to be agile, we are in the fashion business and continue to be to flow the newness, how we are testing and reading and reacting to those. There's still opportunity as to h
componenttext: It's Sharen. I think when you think about Victoria's Secret and as we're continuing to be agile, we are in the fashion business and continue to be to flow the newness, how we are testing and reading and reacting to those. There's still opportunity as to how fast we can get to the big winners. When I think about how we are really focused on with the product meets the customer, that there's always opportunity for improvement, especially when you're looking at 1,000 store chain and also the direct channel. So we do have an initiative this year that how do you even get closer to the customer. When we think about the inefficiencies in the business. So I think if we and the brand continue to have a vision for growth, we do believe there's always opportunities to get better and better, and to think about how we do things differently and especially as we think about what's happening in the social media, and how we utilize our advertising dollars. So it's really a longer conversation, but I think that we have got a lot of great ideas, new initiatives but still focused on our core category to even make Victoria's Secret a better company.

componenttext: I guess we'll say that we very much appreciate the support of the Victoria's Secret brand outside the United States. The simple answer to your question is, no, there are really no box sized compatible with the VS brand, which is multi-sub-brand, and we'll be more flagship oriented as we take it to the rest of the world. And again, I do want to reiterate that we have tremendous confidence in the La Senza brand internationally. It is well distributed. It performs well in 40 over 40 countries today, and we do see that as an opportunity as well.

componenttext: So, Jeff, if you think about the Victoria's Secret perspective, we have to go on a diet. We actually got a little bloated in inventory. headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just recognize that you have more focus on the Canadian retail market than others. What we like the progress is the transformation of the brand in terms of becoming core focus on bras and panties. Less focused on sleepwear but continuing to have assortm
componenttext: I just recognize that you have more focus on the Canadian retail market than others. What we like the progress is the transformation of the brand in terms of becoming core focus on bras and panties. Less focused on sleepwear but continuing to have assortment on the sexy sleepwear. And that transformation, which we also believe is positioning the brand to be younger, fun, flirty, et cetera, is also changing the customer mix. There's a lot of change going on there. And I think I can represent Les is very pleased with the progress that we're making in that kind of a transformation similar to other transformations that I've seen taken from our other brands do over the past 2 decades. The repositioning of the brand imagery, if you've seen the stores in Toronto, John, is working, and we're pleased with that brand positioning. But that's new, and it's not fully distributed throughout Canada yet. So that needs to be fully distributed and proven to be a good brand positioning in terms of store design and imagery and, et cetera. So all works in progress, and we're pleased with the progress were making. It's not yet producing the financial results, as Stuart said, that we would want to and we'll be targeting to produce. In terms of the International business, that is also going through the same kind of transformation. The number of our international franchisees are adopting the new standards, the new store design and positioning and see great success from that. And relatively speaking, I would say the International Franchise business has been performing well than the Canadian business because it's a less competitive market that they're in many of the cases. So are pleased with the progress working closely with a number of our key international franchisees to convert that into this new model, this new brand model.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 19, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're very excited and pleased about the growth that we have seen in our Pink business. We also believe that there's still an enormous amount of opportunity. As you know, we're really not been focused on the bra category. It was really based upon our Loun
componenttext: We're very excited and pleased about the growth that we have seen in our Pink business. We also believe that there's still an enormous amount of opportunity. As you know, we're really not been focused on the bra category. It was really based upon our Lounge business and Panty business. We think there's a big opportunity within that category and getting great traction and success as we go forward. And we also believe that there's another opportunity within the accessory category. Still, continuing to have even more opportunity in the Lounge. So we do believe that this is a powerful brand and a well-told story. As we think about our go-forward strategy, as we can appropriately right-size  Pink within the Victoria's Secret box, we prefer that as a side-by-side. Where we do not, we will be then expanding and opening up freestanding Pink stores. And that is to say, we have about 9 freestanding Pink stores, and we probably still see some more in the future where we just can't get enough real estate for the side-by-side concept. So I think there's opportunity and growth in the bra category and continue apparel category. We have a unique different shade of brown in our collegiate licensing approach program that is so targeted to that market. And then either within the story is our first and second one would be freestanding opportunity.
