headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stephanie. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Limited Brands Second Quarter Earnings Call for the period ending Saturday, July 30, 2011.As a matter of formality, I need to remind you that any forward-looking statements we may make today are
componenttext:
Thanks, Stephanie. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Limited Brands Second Quarter Earnings Call for the period ending Saturday, July 30, 2011.
As a matter of formality, I need to remind you that any forward-looking statements we may make today are subject to our Safe Harbor statement found in our SEC filings. Our first quarter earnings release and related financial information, including any non-GAAP or adjusted financial reconciliation tables, are available on our website, limitedbrands.com. Also available on our website is an investor presentation, which we will be referring to during this call. This call is being taped and can be replayed by dialing 1-866-NEWS-LTD. You can also listen to an audio replay from our website.
Stuart Burgdoerfer, EVP and CFO; and Sharen Turney, CEO of Victoria's Secret; Andrew Mannflow, Chief Administrative Officer of Bath & Body Works; and Martyn Redgrave, EVP and Chief Administrative Officer, are all joining us today. As you know, Medco joined Bath & Body Works in July as CEO. He is still on-boarding and familiarizing himself with the business and will not be joining us on the call today. Many of you know Andrew, an experienced retail executive whose been with Limited Brands for 8 years and at Bath & Body Works for 6 years. After our prepared comments, we will be available to take your questions for as long as time permits. [Operator Instructions] Thanks, and now I'll turn the call over to Stuart.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Amy, and good morning, everyone. We are pleased with our record second quarter performance. Our adjusted earnings per share increased 33% to $0.48 per share versus $0.36 last year. Our reported results of $0.73 per share versus $0.54 last year. Wh
componenttext:
Thanks, Amy, and good morning, everyone. We are pleased with our record second quarter performance. Our adjusted earnings per share increased 33% to $0.48 per share versus $0.36 last year. Our reported results of $0.73 per share versus $0.54 last year. While this and last year's reported results include significant items as detailed in our press release, this year's reported second quarter results includes the following: a nontaxable gain of $147.1 million or $0.47 per share and a pretax expense of $113.4 million or $0.22 per share related to the contribution of all of our remaining expressed shares to the Limited Brands foundation. This contribution allowed us to fund the foundation in a very cash efficient manner. I won't repeat that 2010 significant items, which are detailed in our press release. All results discussed on this call excludes these significant items in both years. 
To take you through the second quarter results, as detailed on Page 4 of the presentation, net sales were $2.458 billion versus $2.2043 billion last year and comps increased 9%. Our other segment revenue increased by $66.4 million or 26% to $324.4 million. Over 75% of the increase was driven by growth in our International business particularly in Canada. The remainder of the increase is primarily attributable to the change in accounting for Mast sales to Express Limited Stores. The gross margin rate increased 200 basis points to 36.7% primarily driven by leverage on buying and occupancy expense. The merchandise margin rate improved slightly despite a negative impact of about 60 basis points related to the increase in Mast sales to Express Limited Stores, which are recognized 100% this year versus 75% last year. We will anniversary this accounting change in the third quarter. 
We continue to focus on managing total expense growth at a rate that is lower than sales. Total expenses the combination of buying and occupancy and SG&A increased by 6% and leverage as a percent of sales. SG&A dollars increased by $54.1 million or 10%, and the SG&A rate increased by 10 basis points. A significant portion of our SG&A is variable, and we will continue to manage that proactively throughout the quarter in response to our sales trend. 2/3 of our SG&A expense growth relates to investments that we made in store selling and marketing to support and drive sales growth. These investments included higher selling payroll and credit card fees related to the growth in sales, increased investment in training and investments in other store initiatives, including technology. The remaining increase in SG&A relates to growth in our home office expense across various categories, including investments related to our International business. 
Turning to operating income on Page 6. Total operating income increased $70.5 million or 30% and 190 basis points as a percent of sales to $307 million or 12.5% of sales. By segment, the Victoria's Secret segment increased by $47.4 million or 200 basis points as a percent of sales to $239 million or 15.2% of sales. Bath & Body Works increased by $5.7 million or 50 basis points as a percent of sales to $70.1 million or 12.5% as a percent of sales. The other segment operating loss improved by $17.5 million to $2.2 million driven by growth in our International business and improve profitability at Mast. Total nonoperating expenses increased by $25.5 million driven by increased interest expense and the loss of income from Express Limited Stores. 
Turning to the balance sheet on Page 10. Retail inventories per square foot at cost and in the quarter down 1% versus last year and down 5% on a 2-year basis. We repurchased 8.2 million shares of stock in the second quarter for $314 million. As of July 30, we had $204 mil remaining under our current $500 million share repurchase program. Turning to Page 11 of the presentation for our forecasting 2011, we expect earnings per share between $0.17 and $0.22 in the third quarter against last year's record, $0.18 result. This forecast will result low- to mid-single-digit comp increase. Our comp estimate for the quarter includes August comps in the high-single-digit range versus our previous guidance for a low-single-digit increase. We expect the third quarter merchandise margin rate to be down somewhat negatively impacted by cost increases. However, this decline should be principally offset by leverage on buying and occupancy costs, so we left the gross margin rate to be about flat. We expect the third quarter SG&A rate to be about flat as well. We expect to end the third quarter with inventory per square foot roughly flat to up slightly to last year. For the full year, we are projecting mid-single-digit positive comps. We continue to expect some impact from increase in cost this fall, and therefore, our outlook doesn't offer some decline in our merchandise margin rate in 2011. We believe that this decline will be more than offset by our buying and occupancy expense leverage, so our forecast for 2011 gross margin rate to be up to last year. We expect the full year SG&a expense rate to leverage slightly on total sales growth. Nonoperating expenses are projected at about $245 million, including principally of interest expense. Before any discrete items, our tax rate will be approximately 38%, and we are forecasting weighted average shares of about 309 million in the third quarter and 315 million for the full year. Assuming all of these inputs, we expect earnings per share for the full year 2011 to be between $2.35 to $2.50 per share. We are projecting 2011 CapEx of about $425 million. 
As detailed on Page 12 of the presentation, we plan to open roughly 40 stores this year and close roughly 50 stores. We'll end the year with total square footage roughly flat to last year. Turning to liquidity. We expect free cash flow in 2011 of about $700 million. We remain committed to returning excess cash to shareholders for a combination of share repurchases and dividend. We took advantage of an attractive bank market in the second quarter by increasing our revolver to $1 billion from $800 million and extending it to 2016. Our free cash flow and cash position, along with additional availability under our revolving credit facility results in strong liquidity, which is more than sufficient to fund our working capital, capital expenditures, dividend and any other receivable need. Thanks, and now I'll turn the discussion over to Sharen.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stuart, and good morning, everyone. Victoria's Secret segment are record operating profit in the second quarter, and we are pleased with this result. This morning, I'll share with you the key drivers of our success. I'll then review second quar
componenttext:
Thank you, Stuart, and good morning, everyone. Victoria's Secret segment are record operating profit in the second quarter, and we are pleased with this result. This morning, I'll share with you the key drivers of our success. I'll then review second quarter financial results and end by briefly discussing how we're thinking about our third quarter. Let's begin with what we have been doing to deliver our results. 
We continue to stay focused on our core categories, bras and panties, supported by a culture that emphasizes getting faster and more agile every day. We remained purposeful in our balanced approach between managing the business with optimism and staying conservative with our inventory and expense plans. We brought this together in a well-told brand story across channel. We told that story through innovative products, steady newness, the right fashion and excellent in-store and online execution. And finally, critical to our success is our customer connection. We work hard everyday to stay close to her and deliver an emotional and positive experience with every interaction. 
Now turning to our financial performance. Our second quarter results are detailed on Page 13 of your presentation materials. In the Victoria's Secret store channel, second quarter comps were up 12%, and total sales were up 11% increasing to $1.064 billion. This result was driven by strength across the assortment. Our Lingerie business in a straight balance growth with bras, panties and sleepwear all performing well. We had a successful semi-annual sales, which resulted higher sell-throughs and very clean inventory positioning heading into the fall season. Pink delivered very strong performance with growth across the assortment driven by both base business and strong customer response to newness. We also continue to improve the integration and quarter nation of our Beauty business with the balance of the store. In July, following the semiannual sales, Beauty reintroduced popular garden line as a remained VS Fantasies collection. As with prior quarters, in-store execution has been critical to our sales growth, and we again achieved record customer conversion for the quarter. And this is the eighth consecutive quarter we have achieved record conversion. The second quarter merchandise margin was up slightly to last year. Margin rate was positively impacted by an increase in full price selling, which was partially offset by product cost increases. We've also leveraged buying and occupancy and SG&A expense, and this combined with our top line growth, drove our operating profit up over 30% versus last year. 
Now let's review performance at Direct. Second quarter sales increased about 1% to $393 million. Top line growth was slow by a 12-day reduction in the spring sales. This strategy was designed to drive more regular price selling, which increased dramatically in the quarter. Swim, Pink and the Active the business were all strong despite the reduction in sale day. With the increase in regular price selling, total gross margin increased significantly. In addition to the fewer days on sale, we were able to offset product cost increases with less, low-margin clearance and selling resulting in a clean inventory position. Even with the slower rate of sales growth, total expenses leveraged in the quarter, so operating income dollars increased 15%, and operating income rate was up significantly. 
Now let's discuss the third quarter. We are cautiously optimistic about the third quarter. We are excited based on our 2 latest launches, Heartbreaker and Showstopper. We will not lose focus on our bras and panties business. These categories are our primary investment heading into all-important holiday time period. We will continue to deliver newness in our assortment and provide customer fresh, innovative product with high emotional content. We will maintain maximum agility to chase what is working and manage any downturn as a result of the macroeconomy. We will stay balanced in our approach by managing our inventory and expenses to grow at a rate slower than sales, and we will chase aggressively where appropriate. 
In closing, we are pleased with our performance but continue to see opportunities for improvement. We will stay close to our customer and work to drive sustained, profitable growth as our top priority. Thank you, and now I'll turn the discussion over to Andrew.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sharen, and good morning, everyone. At Bath & Body Works, we are pleased with the results in the second quarter. We delivered sales and operating income growth versus last year's strong performance. We continue to deliver improved results versu
componenttext:
Thank you, Sharen, and good morning, everyone. At Bath & Body Works, we are pleased with the results in the second quarter. We delivered sales and operating income growth versus last year's strong performance. We continue to deliver improved results versus strong performance last year by maintaining focus on 3 key categories: our Signature Collection product line, the Anti-Bac Sanitizer business and our Home Fragrance assortment. Performance improve result in Signature Collection driven by the launch of the new fragrances like Into The Wild and the new citrus collection. The anti-bac business continued to deliver growth driven by increasing fragrance, novelty and fashion newness in our PocketBac collection. And fragrance sales also grew versus strong performance last year and continue to be driven by candles and new seasonal fragrances, as well as growth in new forms of novelty in our diffuser and scented candle categories. 
Transactions were also up versus last year driven by traffic and continued improvement in our conversion rates. So with that backdrop, let me take you through the financial results for the quarter as detailed on Page 15. Bath & Body Works second quarter comps were up 4%. Total sales for the quarter were $563 million, up 5% or $27 million versus last year. For the quarter, our operating income was $70 million, up $6 million or 9% from last year and up 59% or $26 million from 2 years ago. Operating income as a percent of sales was 12.5% in the quarter and up from last year. Operating income rate in the second quarter was driven by improvement in merchandise margin rate while holding expenses flat as a percent of sales from last year. We also finished the quarter with inventory levels down from last year. We continue to drive inventories down year-over-year start of positions continue to improve. The BBW Direct channel also delivered strong sales and operating income growth versus last year. 
Looking ahead to the third quarter. We will continue to introduce newness and innovation in both home and fragrance. This month, we launched our newest Signature Collection fragrance, and will also continue to introduce novelty in our extended Halloween collection. While the anti-bac and home fragrance businesses have also introduced fashion in newness in fragrances and forms. We are cautiously optimistic about Q3, and we will continue to manage expenses and inventory conservatively. Our overall focus continues to be on getting faster and better and understanding and to satisfy our customer needs while providing them with a world-class, in-store experience. In addition to focusing on product and fragrance launches, we will continue to test and read in the result of new product offerings and promotional strategies while maintaining flexibility in our inventory to react quickly to our customer needs. With that, I'll turn that discussion over to Mark.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew, and good morning, everyone. This morning, I'll focus my remarks on providing an update on our international businesses. As you know, Martin Waters will provide you with more a complete update on our overall international strategy at our in
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew, and good morning, everyone. This morning, I'll focus my remarks on providing an update on our international businesses. As you know, Martin Waters will provide you with more a complete update on our overall international strategy at our investor update meeting in New York in October 19. So I'll only hit the highlights today. 
One of those highlights is that we, along with our partners, continue to be very much on track to open up approximately 130 stores this year outside of the United States. Taking a look at each of the businesses, let's start with the Victoria Secret's international business. In the second quarter, we opened to Victoria's Secret stores in Canada, in Toronto and Calgary, bringing the total in Canada to 6 Victoria's Secret stores and 8 Pink stores. Victoria's continue to do very well and exceeding our sales expectations, and we plan to open another 6 locations in the fall. Our partners opened 6 Victoria's Secret Beauty and accessories stores in the second quarter, bringing the total there to 24 stores. In addition, our partners plan to open another 39 stores by the end of the year. Sales productivity in these stores continue to be very impressive. 
And finally, we continue to be on track to open our flagship store in Bond Street in London next summer. I'm also pleased to announce that we will open another 2 to 3 all assortment mall-based stores in London next summer as well. 
In summary, all of our Victoria's Secret stores outside the United States continue to perform very well, and we are very enthusiastic about global opportunities for this brand. I'll next turn to BBW. We opened 3 stores in Canada in the second quarter bringing our total to 62. These stores continue to achieve sales volumes above our U.S. averages. And we plan to open another 7 stores over the remainder of the year. We opened another 2 stores under our partnership with Alshaya in the Middle East in the second quarter, bringing the total there to 8 stores. These stores also continue to do very well. Our partners will open another 12 stores in the Middle East and Turkey this fall. 
Turning to La Senza. Although business is not significant to our overall results, our Canadian business has been slow to turn around than we would've liked. It's being impacted in part by a very challenging Canadian retail environment, where mall traffic levels will down-low-double digits in the second quarter. La Senza comp store sales increased 1% in the quarter driven by strong semi-annual sales and incremental promotional activity. The La Senza International business has been strong with retail sales up significantly in the quarter. Our partners opened another 9 stores in the second quarter bringing our total to 250 stores, and our partners plan to open another 40 stores in the remainder of the year. Total La Senza operating income was about flat to last year in the quarter and remains at about breakeven. 
In closing, I want to reiterate that we continue to be very pleased with the company's overall record-setting performance. This performance was driven by an intense focus on the fundamentals coupled with an orientation of getting faster and more agile and staying close to our customers. Although we obviously recognize the current environment is very uncertain, we will remain focused on what we can control. We will continue our disciplined and conservative approach to managing business while also aggressively pursuing every opportunity to get even better. Thanks. I'll now turn it back over to Amie.

componenttextpreview: My question is for Stuart. Stuart, the quarter was  so clean. The only thing that stands out here is the lack of SG&A leverage on such an expressive comp, and I'm wondering if you could just help us understand how to think about the SG&A leverage going fo
componenttext: My question is for Stuart. Stuart, the quarter was  so clean. The only thing that stands out here is the lack of SG&A leverage on such an expressive comp, and I'm wondering if you could just help us understand how to think about the SG&A leverage going forward? And should the sales plan exceed your expectation? Are you expecting to ramp SG&A numbers so that you're not really expecting any SG&A leverage as we work our way through the second half of the year?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: On expenses, our view is consistent. It's important to reiterate a few things and that is with respect to total expenses, the company has been and will continue to be very committed to growing expenses slower than sales. And as we were looking back at som
componenttext: On expenses, our view is consistent. It's important to reiterate a few things and that is with respect to total expenses, the company has been and will continue to be very committed to growing expenses slower than sales. And as we were looking back at some things, we've done that for 7 consecutive quarters. And so that commitment is there, and it's in the results. And as you know, Kimberley, our expenses in to categories in buying and occupancy line and in the SG&A line. So with respect to the SG&A component of that, we are managing expenses within the quarter and a lot of the SG&A expenses do reflect with sales. And we're making various investment that Sharen and Andrew could elaborate on if we believe are customer-focused and improve the customer experience and contributing to a very good experience for customers and translate into sales line. But with all that said, very focused on expenses growing slower than sales in which they are. It's part of our cap to '15 framework, which we're making good progress on. And we do manage within the quarter in terms of that sales increase. We're making sure we got the right service experience so we put more hours in the store. For example, that's our biggest category of SG&A expense. And we do make other discreet decision within the quarter that relate to top line results. And we think, overall, it's working pretty well.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: First of all, as we have continued to add more fashion and newness in our product, we have seen price increases but because of the innovation that are putting on the product. In terms of the basic product that we Pink price increases, we always go out and
componenttext: First of all, as we have continued to add more fashion and newness in our product, we have seen price increases but because of the innovation that are putting on the product. In terms of the basic product that we Pink price increases, we always go out and ask people when we do anything. And we have not seen any erosion in terms of taking slight price increases. And it's a very important for us to continue to balance unit and dollar growth in our path to continue to drive more market share.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Similar to what Sharen just described about Bodyworks, we have seen some cost increases quite a bit by the investments that we've made into our product in terms of innovation as well. To what Sharen has described, Bath & Body Works is consistent about tes
componenttext: Similar to what Sharen just described about Bodyworks, we have seen some cost increases quite a bit by the investments that we've made into our product in terms of innovation as well. To what Sharen has described, Bath & Body Works is consistent about testing all those types of price increases that we might think to offset cost increases, and more primarily on making sure that the pricing value equation we offer to our customers are appropriate for the investment that we make in innovation, newness and fashion. And as a Sharen said, we also have not seen any resistance from those price increases at this point.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: So, Stuart, how do we tie that together with the merchandise margin assumptions for the third quarter? And don't you also get a boost from anniversarying the change of accounting for Mast sales?
componenttext: So, Stuart, how do we tie that together with the merchandise margin assumptions for the third quarter? And don't you also get a boost from anniversarying the change of accounting for Mast sales?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: I want to make this clear to everybody. This phenomena in the third quarter particularly in the fall, to a lesser extent, is as we've talked about the price increases generally are back half weighted to the fall versus the spring, just based on the trend
componenttext: I want to make this clear to everybody. This phenomena in the third quarter particularly in the fall, to a lesser extent, is as we've talked about the price increases generally are back half weighted to the fall versus the spring, just based on the trend of input increases, including cotton and how the sell-through inventory. So that half way is consistent with prior commentary. And particularly in the third quarter, Paul, our personal care and beauty side of the business makes a slight. And the Pink business talking about percent of sales. And so as you would appreciate, the Pink and Victoria's Secret Direct businesses are impacted to a greater extent in Personal Care Beauty on the cost side. And their portion of the business in Q3 is greater than for the full year and certainly for the fourth quarter. So there's an effect that impact the third quarter based on just the seasonality of the respective businesses is an important contributor to.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Does that mean we should expect merch margins up in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Does that mean we should expect merch margins up in the fourth quarter?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll get you that guidance, but we Pink there's going to be some may be down slightly in the fourth quarter, offset by leverage so gross margin rate should be flattish with some ongoing pressure with gross margin rate.
componenttext: We'll get you that guidance, but we Pink there's going to be some may be down slightly in the fourth quarter, offset by leverage so gross margin rate should be flattish with some ongoing pressure with gross margin rate.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Black with Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Black with Citigroup.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Staying that line, thinking if you don't mind, on the cost side so, Stuart, you're saying the cost increases are really baked into the cake through 4Q this year? Could you just give us some clarity on that? And have you seen cost start to come down a litt
componenttext: Staying that line, thinking if you don't mind, on the cost side so, Stuart, you're saying the cost increases are really baked into the cake through 4Q this year? Could you just give us some clarity on that? And have you seen cost start to come down a little bit. And if so, given the way we're managing the Victoria's Secret business, might we be able to take advantage of that sooner rather than later?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, our views of cost and our knowledge of our cost are fully reflected in our guidance. So what we know about cost is included in our Q3 and full year guidance, so it's all baked in, to use your metaphor. And with respect to cost generally. Again this i
componenttext: Yes, our views of cost and our knowledge of our cost are fully reflected in our guidance. So what we know about cost is included in our Q3 and full year guidance, so it's all baked in, to use your metaphor. And with respect to cost generally. Again this is the most important thing about discussion, which we started our commentary on it at the beginning of the year is, while cost are important and we're talking about it a little here in the third quarter because it has an effect particularly in the third quarter, it's important to remember what this business is about, which is about differentiation, about emotional content, about creating value for customers, about speed and agility and more full-priced selling, which we're realizing. So we don't want too much emphasis to be put on the cost side of the business because where we created value for more than 4 years is through emotional content for customers, and that's what we're most focused on. While there is the price of cotton come down, and we look at it up in the exchange, it looks like it's coming down, how that will affect our business, we'll see. But again, that's not what our primary focus is. It's about customers and emotional content, innovation.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jennifer Davis with Lazard Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jennifer Davis with Lazard Capital Markets.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me add my congratulations, and I will move away from the cost First, a clarification, on the other segment income, did you book any upfront royalties or anything like that in the second quarter? And then my question is about Victoria's Secret Beauty a
componenttext: Let me add my congratulations, and I will move away from the cost First, a clarification, on the other segment income, did you book any upfront royalties or anything like that in the second quarter? And then my question is about Victoria's Secret Beauty and accessories stores, where are those 39 going to be opening? Is that going to be in the Middle East and Turkey, or other airport locations? And how are they structured? Are they franchise or licensed, or are they kind of a wholesale model? Or how many stores do you think that you can hope a long term and how many annually in the future?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: So on the other segment, Jennifer, there's not anything significant related to upfront fees in the second quarter results. There is nothing significant in Q2 in the other segment on upfront fees.
componenttext: So on the other segment, Jennifer, there's not anything significant related to upfront fees in the second quarter results. There is nothing significant in Q2 in the other segment on upfront fees.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jennifer, it's Martyn. In terms of Victoria's Secret Beauty and accessories stores, obviously, we're signaling a large number of stores balance of the year, 39. And they will be a distributed broadly across the globe, frankly. I mean, Asia, Europe, the Mi
componenttext: Jennifer, it's Martyn. In terms of Victoria's Secret Beauty and accessories stores, obviously, we're signaling a large number of stores balance of the year, 39. And they will be a distributed broadly across the globe, frankly. I mean, Asia, Europe, the Middle East, Turkey, South America even in the U.S. actually. There's a couple of the airport stores in the U.S. like JFK that are included in the total numbers that I'm describing. So we continue to see that as concept that can travel well, not only in India, but potentially off-airport as we're starting to do more and more of. And it really leads to Victoria's Secret brand into the rest of the world. It kind of seeds brand with customers gives us read and react perception of how the customer is reacting to the brand, which has been fabulous. And we continue to see that as a big part of our way forward. In terms of the structure of the business, we are moving that business more and more to a traditional franchise structure not royalty-based. There will be continuos relationship that will be more in the wholesale model because of the duty-free operations in airports. But more dominantly, that will be franchise versus wholesale, and we see a great future for it.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of how many we see annually either for next year and long term, we'll probably get more into that as our Update Meeting in October when Martin Waters will do a complete overview of our international strategy.
componenttext: In terms of how many we see annually either for next year and long term, we'll probably get more into that as our Update Meeting in October when Martin Waters will do a complete overview of our international strategy.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Stacy Pak from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stacy Pak from Barclays Capital.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, my question is a little more on the international, the Victoria's Secret flagship and the mall stores around it. Are you thinking franchise or owned now? And how are you sort of thinking about those mall stores? How long are you going to watch, s
componenttext: I guess, my question is a little more on the international, the Victoria's Secret flagship and the mall stores around it. Are you thinking franchise or owned now? And how are you sort of thinking about those mall stores? How long are you going to watch, sort of what are the next steps from there? And then also La Senza openings here domestically, how are you thinking about that now?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Martyn for that question.
componenttext: We'll go to Martyn for that question.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the Victoria's Secret stores, the one I was describing for London, the best way to describe the mall-base stores is the equivalent of full assortment A mall, large box store in the United States. And that's what we are looking to do as we expand in the
componenttext: On the Victoria's Secret stores, the one I was describing for London, the best way to describe the mall-base stores is the equivalent of full assortment A mall, large box store in the United States. And that's what we are looking to do as we expand in the U.K. in particular those will be company-owned and company operated in the U.K. For other parts of the world, we would plan as we consistently said, like model and will do our franchise partners for instance Alshaya business in the Middle East.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Does that mean Europe will be company-owned and elsewhere in the world is franchised?
componenttext: Does that mean Europe will be company-owned and elsewhere in the world is franchised?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have not made a decision beyond the U.K. being company-owned. That's still something that we're very much in the learning phase on. And as we can consistently do expect, we're taking a very careful test, to pilot and then roll, country-by-country and r
componenttext: We have not made a decision beyond the U.K. being company-owned. That's still something that we're very much in the learning phase on. And as we can consistently do expect, we're taking a very careful test, to pilot and then roll, country-by-country and relationship-by-relationship approach. And we feel that's a prudent and appropriate way for us to deliver our brands to the rest of the world. So no decision on Europe either if it's company-owned or franchised. And we don't have any other specific announcements to make about additional franchise, partner relationships at this stage. But again, as I've mentioned in my prepared remarks, we do plan to give a full and complete update on this with Martin Waters at our International business in our October Investor Update Meeting.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And On the La Senza?
componenttext: Okay. And On the La Senza?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of La Senza coming in the United States, I think the first and foremost priority for us is the turnaround of La Senza in Canada. We see this as a future opportunity. It could be a potential big and exciting opportunity. But our first priority is
componenttext: In terms of La Senza coming in the United States, I think the first and foremost priority for us is the turnaround of La Senza in Canada. We see this as a future opportunity. It could be a potential big and exciting opportunity. But our first priority is to complete the work that is in progress around the brand repositioning, the assortment repositioning and really making that brand into that kind of brand that we wanted to be both in the sales productivity and profitability perspective in Canada, and then will bring that to the United States.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro from The Retail Tracker.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro from The Retail Tracker.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about the marketing as a go internationally for Victoria's Secret, what your partners are doing on the marketing side? Are they mailing catalogs at all? And if you can talk a little bit about your Catalog business here in the U
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about the marketing as a go internationally for Victoria's Secret, what your partners are doing on the marketing side? Are they mailing catalogs at all? And if you can talk a little bit about your Catalog business here in the U.S. I know for the most part the Direct business is online, but if you taken down your circulation, have you put those cost savings back into the online business or back in the overall marketing budget?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: So we'll go to Sharen first for the Direct question.
componenttext: So we'll go to Sharen first for the Direct question.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: What we think about our Catalog business, we really don't think of it as a separate business. We really think about it as a one business in terms of the direct channel. We continue to be more efficient with our catalog and we continue to reinvent that int
componenttext: What we think about our Catalog business, we really don't think of it as a separate business. We really think about it as a one business in terms of the direct channel. We continue to be more efficient with our catalog and we continue to reinvent that into our online strategy, both from the social perspective, as well as from the commerce perspective. So I think that we're pretty excited about some of the new things that we're doing in terms of restaging our catalogs and now are using them in order to drive the online business, but really thinking about it how it tries to store business as well from a one-customer perspective.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then Martyn for...
componenttext: And then Martyn for...

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of the international marketing approach, again, the key is translating in delivering the U.S. brand as it is presented into the customer into the United States to our international customers. So that's the starting point, which means that we're u
componenttext: In terms of the international marketing approach, again, the key is translating in delivering the U.S. brand as it is presented into the customer into the United States to our international customers. So that's the starting point, which means that we're using the marketing, the marketing calendar, the marketing visual, merchandising and everything else that comes out of the United States for BBW. Victoria's Secret Beauty and accessories is an interpretation, obviously, of what VS is doing in the U.S. and then for La Senza is an ongoing position. Obviously, by geography, that marketing needs to be translated into foreign languages in some cases and needs to be sensitized to local practices and customers for instance of the Middle East, so there are modifications that are being made as we provide services to our franchisees.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Neely Tamminga from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Neely Tamminga from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've got a lot of cost cuts going on this week through earnings season and you guys taking out your outlook for August as completely commendable. I am wondering now if there's anything you're seeing in the underlying metrics I'll ask specifically, to Stu
componenttext: We've got a lot of cost cuts going on this week through earnings season and you guys taking out your outlook for August as completely commendable. I am wondering now if there's anything you're seeing in the underlying metrics I'll ask specifically, to Stuart in terms of traffic conversion that's telling you that she is acting differently this month versus last month? In a very related fashion, just a quick work from Sharen and from Andrew on behalf of BBW, what could you guys do if things do go a little bit sour between now and September repositioning the holiday?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we'll go to Sharen and Andrew actually for both of those. So first on what you're seeing in August versus previously. Basically, the traffic [indiscernible] That traffic has been slightly down, really across the mall, and we were really seeing the
componenttext: I think we'll go to Sharen and Andrew actually for both of those. So first on what you're seeing in August versus previously. Basically, the traffic [indiscernible] That traffic has been slightly down, really across the mall, and we were really seeing the benefit to our conversion. I think that your question about how quickly can we respond to the market, one of our true focus is, how do we really think agile in terms of hoping to buy, positioning from a speed perspective. And we have on that in sight to both maximize the outside, as well as to be able to balance our business if there's any downturn with the macroeconomic. We definitely know that it's unstable out there, and that's just our thinking about it. It's how we continue to put the maximum amount of agility into the business. So we do have opportunities to be able to assess the fourth quarter. We're in the throes right now of tapping big key items for the holiday. So I think we're trying to balance that conservatism and optimism, as well as we can. And, Andrew?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Andrew. So to your question on August, I would say for Bath & Body Works, the trend we're seeing for August on traffic and conversion is similar to what we've been seeing in the past. We do have some timing differences this month, as I mentioned earl
componenttext: It's Andrew. So to your question on August, I would say for Bath & Body Works, the trend we're seeing for August on traffic and conversion is similar to what we've been seeing in the past. We do have some timing differences this month, as I mentioned earlier, in the prepared remarks. We have launched a new Signature Collection, fragrance Paris Amore, this month that is incremental to last year, and we did not have one in August last year. And we are, so far, a few days into that launch. I'm very pleased with the performance we're seeing in all metrics attributed with that launch. In terms of our flexibility for the back half, I can agree with everything that Sharen said. In a similar way, we plan conservatively going into the season in terms of how we have inventory position. We have used our speed initiatives to get to the flexibility to either chase with any upside or react in cuts with any downside. In a similar way, our promotional activity, we go into every season planning to essentially anniversary prior year promotional activity. And as we get in-season, we are flexible to ramp that down if we see better performance in full price selling as we did in the spring season or if necessary is the macro environment were to worsen, we can obviously ramp that up as well. So again in a very similar way, a lot of flexibility to react in the season.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michelle Tan with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michelle Tan with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Following upon some of the international questions, I was wondering if you could give us a sense of what the lead times look like for opening mall-based stores for you that are company-owned as opposed to flagship? So if these stores that you're opening n
componenttext: Following upon some of the international questions, I was wondering if you could give us a sense of what the lead times look like for opening mall-based stores for you that are company-owned as opposed to flagship? So if these stores that you're opening next in the U.K. really exceed your expectation, how quickly could you really ramp up that growth? How soon before we start seeing more U.K. stores open?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Martyn for that question.
componenttext: We'll go to Martyn for that question.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of lead times, again, I'm going to retreat a couple of points, we're in morning journey. We're taking that journey in a very careful way, which is we're test things carefully, we're going to read and react to the results, and then we're going to
componenttext: In terms of lead times, again, I'm going to retreat a couple of points, we're in morning journey. We're taking that journey in a very careful way, which is we're test things carefully, we're going to read and react to the results, and then we're going to decide whether we've got something that's working as we intended it to work, and then we'll go and decide to rollout that concept or wherever we're talking about going. So in the case of the U.K. stores, the mall-based stores, we'll be more like in the U.S. tour, but it's the U.K., not the United States. So we need to learn about that. If the lead times are similar to the U.S., all gated on the availability of the right side and the right place as it would be in the United States. And obviously, it's different than what a major high street flagship store like Bond Street would be.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Stein with Ticonderoga Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Stein with Ticonderoga Securities.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering the franchise model internationally, are there wholesale sales that are being reflected on the other line and has that been a material driver to sales and profitability?
componenttext: I'm wondering the franchise model internationally, are there wholesale sales that are being reflected on the other line and has that been a material driver to sales and profitability?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: The other segment includes all the retail sales and revenues as we recall, which will be royalties and wholesale revenues from the BBW, Victoria's Secret Beauty and Accessories and most Victoria's Secret store, Pink store businesses, the La Senza business
componenttext: The other segment includes all the retail sales and revenues as we recall, which will be royalties and wholesale revenues from the BBW, Victoria's Secret Beauty and Accessories and most Victoria's Secret store, Pink store businesses, the La Senza business is included in the Victoria's Secret segment. And so, yes, the revenues that are being produced from our expansion to 130 stores that I'm describing that we'll open this year is all be reported except for the La Senza business and that other segment.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: And has it been a material driver to sales and profitability?
componenttext: And has it been a material driver to sales and profitability?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: It has not.
componenttext: It has not.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: In the aggregate, no.
componenttext: In the aggregate, no.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Omar Saad from ISI Group.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Omar Saad from ISI Group.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: I know you guys don't have a crystal ball, you've stated volatility and negative headlines out there. Could you just spend a couple of minutes reminding us having just gone through, obviously, a very significant recession a couple of years ago. What parts
componenttext: I know you guys don't have a crystal ball, you've stated volatility and negative headlines out there. Could you just spend a couple of minutes reminding us having just gone through, obviously, a very significant recession a couple of years ago. What parts of the business do you feel most confident in and positioning on the consumer side or the channels, whether it's Victoria's Secret or Pink, Bath & Body, the Direct business versus the in-store business or the Mast business. Could you help us remind us, which part of the company you intended to hold up much better into recession-type scenario. Obviously, we don't know if we're headed there yet.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hopefully, we're not, Omar.
componenttext: Hopefully, we're not, Omar.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sharen or Andrew may want to add in running of the businesses, from an overall perspective, the CEO, we're focused on what we can control and what we've been doing over the last 3 or 4 years in particular is focusing on a very few things that are fundamen
componenttext: Sharen or Andrew may want to add in running of the businesses, from an overall perspective, the CEO, we're focused on what we can control and what we've been doing over the last 3 or 4 years in particular is focusing on a very few things that are fundamental in the matters of the customer. And so that's about newness, it's about fashion, it's about managing inventory with speed, agility, handling expenses with discipline, flexibility capital spending and flexibility cash liquidity, all those things in a prudent thoughtful way, again, focused on what we can control. And that mantra hasn't changed. It served as well in very difficult times, the late '08 through the early part of '09. And it continues to serve as well this year, and it's our game plan going forward. And so that's our mindset about it, focus on what we can control, and focus and a few things that are fundamental and a really matter to the customer. That's what working in our business and that will remain in our mindset.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Randy Koenig from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Randy Koenig from Jefferies.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: This question is for Martyn, you kind of said several times these are our partners with international strategy. Just trying to get a sense of when you say the word partners, are we looking at how many partners are you looking at country partner strategy,
componenttext: This question is for Martyn, you kind of said several times these are our partners with international strategy. Just trying to get a sense of when you say the word partners, are we looking at how many partners are you looking at country partner strategy, content partner strategy? And then on a similarity you're seeing the types of businesses these partners had and anything you can progress with the economic model of the strategy with the partners not citing specific deal terms?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Martyn.
componenttext: We'll go to Martyn.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I'm going to promise to do more on this on the October investor update. I think obviously, there's a real desire for a deep dive on this, and we will do that in the October meeting. When we use the word partner, it obviously does define franchisee. It
componenttext: And I'm going to promise to do more on this on the October investor update. I think obviously, there's a real desire for a deep dive on this, and we will do that in the October meeting. When we use the word partner, it obviously does define franchisee. It defines partners in the airport mall. We do like the word partner because we really do believe that people we're entering into these relationships with need to be our partners, and we need to be great partners to them. So regardless of legal form, we're going to use the word partners, and we intend to do -- expand to partnerships across the globe. And I think that's really all I could say for today, but we will kind of take you through more about the business, more about economic model of it as we see it growing and emerging in the October investor update.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are you looking more of a concentrated partner strategy per country, or are you looking at multiple, multiple partners in Canada or outside U.K. and Europe?
componenttext: Are you looking more of a concentrated partner strategy per country, or are you looking at multiple, multiple partners in Canada or outside U.K. and Europe?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: The model might be what we're doing in the Alshaya relationship in the Middle East. We obviously, our La Senza business had multiple partners. But I think we will be more oriented towards concentrating on key partner relationships as opposed to hundreds o
componenttext: The model might be what we're doing in the Alshaya relationship in the Middle East. We obviously, our La Senza business had multiple partners. But I think we will be more oriented towards concentrating on key partner relationships as opposed to hundreds of relationships.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dana Telsey from Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dana Telsey from Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: As you think about the gross margin and the complexion of the gross margin, can you give break out the complexion in terms of how the bucket work merchandise margin, what to expect going forward? I know you mentioned it earlier, is their continuity in tha
componenttext: As you think about the gross margin and the complexion of the gross margin, can you give break out the complexion in terms of how the bucket work merchandise margin, what to expect going forward? I know you mentioned it earlier, is their continuity in that? And also the complexion of inventory in terms of unit and dollar gain. And lastly, as you expand overseas, how do you see pricing from Victoria's Secret overseas as compared to the U.S.?

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Stuart.
componenttext: We'll go to Stuart.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: As we commented on our prepared remarks and some of the Q&A previously, there's going to be some pressure on the merchandise margin line in the back half of the year. And we expect to get some leverage on the buying and occupancy line also. And those 2 th
componenttext: As we commented on our prepared remarks and some of the Q&A previously, there's going to be some pressure on the merchandise margin line in the back half of the year. And we expect to get some leverage on the buying and occupancy line also. And those 2 things largely offset for a flattish gross margin rate for the balance of the year. So that's our view and we'll obviously maximize the results on a dollar rate basis, but that's an ongoing assumption. With respect to inventory, 3 or 4 messages, statistics, we're very focused on the management team here, very focused on. With respect to growth, we expect flattish inventory per foot maybe up slightly by month but clearly well below sales results. So that discipline continues. Clearly, there are some differences between unit growth and dollar growth, depending upon what part of the business you are talking about. We're not going to go into great detail about that, but there are some differences depending upon what part of your business you're looking at. And when you look at that units and dollars all the time, both on a selling basis and inventory position basis. But again, I don't think meaningful to the overall understanding of our managing our inventory. What's most important is we're at clearly focus on growing inventories slower than sales, improving turn and continuing to get better with speed and agility, which we've made progress on, but we're working hard to even make more progress. We think there's a lot more opportunity.

headline: Limited Brands, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of pricing overseas, I think, as you know, most international or global retailers have a variety of different pricing schemes country-by-country, kind of case-by-case. We would see in a similar way in Canada we have parity pricing, plus or minus.
componenttext: In terms of pricing overseas, I think, as you know, most international or global retailers have a variety of different pricing schemes country-by-country, kind of case-by-case. We would see in a similar way in Canada we have parity pricing, plus or minus. In other geographies, we might have, as other retailers do, a price premium, 10% to 30%. But it's going to be case-by-case, country-by-country, and we'll test and learn our way through the right price to value relationship is for each country that we operate in.
